column2: Body

Write a page containing the official DDS Spejderloven text. Provide the exact wording for all points of the law and prepare to link it when referenced by other pages. Purpose: establish a common values foundation for all sea scouts.

Write a page that explains how each point of the Spejderloven is applied in practice on the water. For each law point, describe behaviors and good seamanship examples, plus reflection questions for patrols. Purpose: translate values into everyday sea scout behavior.

Write a page explaining the seven elements of the Spejdermetoden (scout method) and link each to specific sea-scout activities (patrol system, learning-by-doing, friluftsliv, personal development, etc.). Purpose: help scouts understand why training is structured as it is.

Create a page describing patrol roles for Optimist/jolle sailing: helm, crew, equipment manager, safety lead, etc., and how to rotate roles. Purpose: build self-sufficient patrols and clarify responsibilities.
Create a page describing roles on the J/70 (helm, trimmer, tactician, bow) with responsibilities and standard commands. Purpose: teach teamwork and safety on larger keelboats.
Write a page about the buddy system and communication within the patrol. Explain check-ins, hand signals and call words. Purpose: prevent accidents and reinforce group cohesion.

Provide a template for briefing and debriefing before/after sailing: goals, area, weather, safety, focus exercise, roles, reflection questions. Purpose: ensure consistent, scout-led routines for each session.

Create landing pages for common badges: Småbådssejler, Gast, Kaptajn, Sømil, Svømmer, Bål, Bålkok, Kniv, Førstehjælp, Klar dig selv. For each, list requirements in plain language, recommended training, and link to relevant wiki pages. Purpose: connect badge goals to training resources.

Write a page about personal safety equipment: types of life jackets and proper fit, clothing layers for temperature and wind, personal kit (knife, whistle, sunscreen, water, snacks). Purpose: minimize risk and teach self-preparation.

Create checklists for trip preparation for each boat type (Optimist, Jolle, J/70) including equipment, weather limits, area selection, crew and communication checks. Purpose: standardize pre-sail routines and avoid critical oversights.

Write a page describing the step-by-step man overboard procedure for Optimist and small dinghies: stop, turn back, approach from leeward, throw line, calmly rescue. Purpose: teach safe responses in an emergency on small boats.

Write a page describing the man overboard procedure for the J/70/keelboats: shout/point, press MOB button, sail upwind, approach under control, rescue with hypothermia focus. Purpose: ensure safe, coordinated recovery on larger boats.

Write a page covering the signs of cold shock and hypothermia, actions to take, when to stop sailing, and basic first aid for minor injuries (cuts, rope burns, booms). Purpose: teach scouts to recognize and respond to cold and injuries.

Write a page with clear 'if-then' emergency scenarios: capsize far from shore, injury, fog, missing boat. Explain who to contact and which signals to use. Purpose: give scouts a clear action plan for emergencies.

Write a page introducing wind directions relative to the boat: no-sail zone, close-hauled, beam reach, broad reach, run. Include diagrams and simple exercises. Purpose: provide common language for sailing and understanding maneuvers.

column1: Sejl som vinge & fart vs højde
column2: Write a page explaining how sails generate lift and drag (wing principle) and the trade-off between speed (fart) and pointing high (højde). Purpose: give intuitive understanding of why sail trim matters.

Write a page teaching weight placement for control: fore/aft and windward/leeward positions, hiking, stability. Purpose: show that body position is essential to steering and balance, often more than the rudder.

Write a page about proper rudder use: small corrections vs major turns, rudder as brake, and techniques for stopping and controlling speed. Purpose: avoid oversteering and develop boat handling finesse.

Write a page explaining drift caused by wind and current. Teach simple rules to anticipate and compensate for leeway and current. Purpose: help scouts understand why they don’t stay on a straight line and adjust course.
Write a page on sailing in waves: how to time tacks and jibes in choppy water, how waves affect boat speed and handling. Purpose: improve control and safety when conditions are rough.
Write a step-by-step rigging guide for the Optimist with photos or diagrams, including a checklist for 8–12 year olds. Purpose: enable scouts to prepare their boat independently and safely.
Create a page detailing how to trim the Optimist sail for different wind ranges (0–3, 4–7, 8–12, 13+ m/s). Purpose: provide quick reference for improving speed and control in varying conditions.

Write a page covering key Optimist maneuvers: tacking, gybing, stopping, starting, and mark roundings. Include step-by-step instructions and common mistakes. Purpose: teach fundamental maneuvers for dinghy sailors.
Create a troubleshooting page listing common Optimist problems (e.g., boat stops during tacks, sail flutters) with causes and fixes. Purpose: help scouts diagnose and correct mistakes quickly.
Write a page about caring for the Optimist: cleaning the hull, checking sails and lines, winter storage. Purpose: extend equipment life and ensure readiness for each season.
Create a page explaining crew roles on the J/70 (helm, trimmer, tactician, bow) and standard commands. Purpose: improve teamwork and safety on bigger boats.
Write a step-by-step rigging guide for the J/70 including mast, shrouds, sails and safety checks. Purpose: help crews set up the boat correctly and efficiently.

Write a page providing baseline trim advice for the J/70: how to set the main, jib and gennaker for various wind conditions, including control lines (vang, cunningham, barber haulers). Purpose: improve speed and handling.
Create a page detailing gennaker maneuvers: hoisting, dropping, gybing, and mark roundings. Provide flow diagrams and roles. Purpose: teach safe and efficient spinnaker handling.
Write a page about safety practices on the J/70: line discipline, cockpit organization, winch use, avoiding collisions. Purpose: prevent injuries and boat damage.
Write a page introducing J/70 racing: start procedures, laylines, mark rounding rules and fair play. Purpose: prepare 12–16 year olds for regatta participation.

Write a general dinghy page for single- and double-handed boats beyond Optimist: rigging basics, capsize and righting techniques, standard maneuvers, common mistakes and maintenance. Purpose: cover all small boat types used by the group.

Create individual or grouped pages for essential knots (pælestik, ottetalsknob, flagknob, råbåndsknob, skødestik, halvstik). For each: describe purpose, step-by-step tying instructions, errors to avoid and practice exercises. Purpose: ensure scouts master core knots.

Write a page introducing advanced knots for 12–16 year olds: anchor hitch, prusik, double bowline and splice (splidsning). Describe use cases in towing and rescue. Purpose: equip older scouts for more complex situations.
Write a page on rope work: proper mooring techniques, setting fenders, towing/assistance procedures, storage and care of lines. Purpose: apply knot skills in real scenarios.

Create a page summarizing the five most important sailing rules for beginners: keeping lookout, safe speed, right-of-way situations (sail vs motor, meeting, crossing, overtaking), and caution in narrow channels. Use diagrams and simple quizzes. Purpose: build basic rule awareness.

Write an advanced page covering special vessels, rules in reduced visibility, sound signals, and night sailing. Include complex scenario quizzes for 12–16 year olds. Purpose: deepen knowledge for experienced scouts.

Write a page on lighthouses: purpose, light characteristics (Fl, Oc, Iso, LFl, Q), reading sector lights (red/green/white) and ranges, and examples on charts. Include a recognition quiz. Purpose: teach navigation by lights.

Write a page explaining navigation lights: configurations for sailboats and motorboats, lights for small boats under 7 m, towing and fishing vessels. Include a 'name that vessel' quiz with light patterns. Purpose: enable scouts to recognize vessels and act accordingly at night.

Create a page covering buoyage: lateral marks (red/green), cardinal marks (N/E/S/W with memory tricks), safe water marks, isolated danger and special marks. Explain how to interpret them on charts and the water. Include a practice quiz. Purpose: help scouts navigate channels and avoid hazards.

Write a page introducing basic navigation: what is a nautical chart, depth and color coding, key symbols (rocks, cables, restricted zones), using a compass, setting a course and simple bearings, using GPS responsibly, and planning a simple A→B route. Purpose: provide fundamental nav skills for all sailors.

Write an advanced navigation page for 12–16 year olds: concepts of leeway and current, calculating position from two bearings, laylines for racing, route planning with primary/secondary plans and emergency options, night and fog navigation, safe coastal sailing. Include practice exercises. Purpose: prepare older scouts for independent sailing.

Write a page explaining what VHF radio is and why we use it, the role of channel 16 as distress/calling/monitoring channel, and the limitations of mobile phones. Purpose: ensure scouts understand the importance of radio communications.

Create a page describing radio certifications (SRC), the age requirement (15+), and group policy: younger scouts may use radio only under leader supervision. Purpose: promote legal and safe radio use.

Write a page listing the group’s working channels and typical inter-ship channels (e.g. 72/77), plus how to call up using a standard format ('receiver receiver receiver, this is ...'). Purpose: teach proper radio discipline and channel use.

Write a page on distress calls: when and how to use MAYDAY and PAN-PAN, what information to include (boat name/call sign, position, nature of distress, assistance needed, number of people), and using the DSC distress button if present. Purpose: ensure all scouts know emergency radio procedures.

Write a page on knife and tool safety: proper knife handling, whittling techniques, maintenance, and introduction to saw and axe for 12–16 year olds. Purpose: promote safe use of tools and satisfy badge requirements.

Create a page on fire craft: fire safety, lighting and materials, types of campfires (tipi, pagoda, star fire), cooking in wet weather, extinguishing and Leave No Trace. Include separate cooking suggestions for 8–12 and 12–16. Purpose: support outdoor skills and badge work.

Write a page covering basic lashings and knots for structures, rope choice and safety, and small sea-scout projects like boat stands, drying racks and simple floating platforms. Purpose: teach construction skills and connect rope work to practical projects.

Write a page on camping and trip life: packing lists for day/overnight/summer trips, patrol kitchen routines, hygiene, environmental considerations, camp set-up, logbook and watch schedules for older scouts. Purpose: prepare scouts for independent camp experiences.

Compile a bank of training exercises across topics: each exercise should include purpose, setup, step-by-step instructions, variations and debrief questions. Purpose: provide leaders with ready-made activities to support learning.
Design a 4-week training progression for beginners with increasing complexity across boat handling, safety and seamanship. Purpose: ensure a clear learning pathway for younger scouts.

Design an 8-week training progression for older scouts, including J/70 practice, advanced navigation, racing introduction and leadership roles. Purpose: prepare for advanced sailing and leadership responsibilities.

Create quizzes and one-page cheatsheets for knots, COLREG scenarios, lantern and buoy recognition, VHF protocols and sail trim. Purpose: provide fun revision tools and quick references for scouts and leaders.

Write a page describing the style guidelines for the wiki: tone, length, structure, use of headings and age boxes, linking practice and image placement. Purpose: maintain consistency across contributions.

Write a page for group-specific information: local waters, harbor regulations, emergency contacts, weather limits, group working channels. Purpose: tailor the wiki to your local environment and needs.
